title.rendered: Home Safety Tips For The Seniors In Your Life

content.rendered:
When you have an elderly parent or family member who lives alone, you may experience a range of thoughts and feelings. You might be happy that they live in the comfort of their own house, where they have a sense of independence and security. On the other side, you may be continually concerned for their safety and well-being. Living alone could be perceived as a mark of independence, however, it also can put individuals at risk of psychological issues such as loneliness and isolation, as well as physical health issues such as falls and other risks.

Listed below are some home safety guidance to help keep your seniors safe and independent for as long as possible. We’re also providing recommendations on how to recognize when it’s time to consider assisted living.

Clear the Clutter

Falls are the leading causal factor of injury among the elderly. Many falls, however, can be avoided by maintaining the home clear of clutter and other risks. Here are some things you can do to assist fall-proof your elders’ house:

Keep the Room Clutter-Free – Clutter not only adds stress but can also be a physical threat. Verify that your elders’ house, mainly the floor area, is free of stacks of clothing, books, pet toys, or other random objects that might make it difficult to navigate or easy to fall.

Remove Any Unwanted Throw Rugs – Try to keep the number of carpets and runners in your elder’s house to a minimum. Since they can be safely placed on slippery, wooden floors, be sure that each rug has a slip-resistant rubber backing.

Messy Cords and Wires Should Be Avoided – Extending extension cables over the floor might be a significant problem. If they must be kept, attempt to conceal them with furniture or tape the cables to the floor using duct tape.

Keep Your Elder’s Home Clean

Sometimes elderly people can have difficulty cleaning hard-to-reach areas in the bathroom, replacing air filters, or performing regular cleaning and maintenance. It can lead to health risks such as mold and dust, which can aggravate some health issues.

To prevent this, make sure your elders’ house is thoroughly cleaned at least once a month to avoid mold and dust from forming.

Keep Emergency Number on Hand

In an emergency, your elderly may not be relaxed or technologically competent enough to pick up a phone number. To assist them, make a list of emergency numbers and contacts and put it somewhere easily accessible.

Maintain Stair Safety

If your elders’ house includes stairs, ensure that the stairs are strong and safe, with no loose rails. Clear all clutter from the stairs and make sure there is enough illumination above the steps. When your parent has difficulty distinguishing between the stages, apply a strip of strikingly different colored tape on each one.

Is Time to Consider Assisted Living?

It is vital for maintaining your parents’ house as secure as possible, it’s not always enough to keep them safe, cheerful, and healthy. Listed below are some signs indicating that your parent(s) could no longer survive safely alone and might benefit from a social setting such as assisted living.

  • Despite taking measures at home, they recently fell.
  • They are experiencing difficulty maintaining the house, and it is in a condition of neglect or disorder.
  • They could no longer shop or cook for themselves.
  • They can’t walk up the stairs securely or freely anymore.
  • They are unable to manage their funds and routinely miss bills and payments.
  • They have gotten more alone and socially withdrawn as a result of their isolation, and they would benefit from socialization.
  • You can no longer check in on them as frequently due to personal health and responsibilities.
